content: The Act is known as the "HALT Campus Sexual Violence Act" and requires disclosure of enforcement actions. The Department of Education Organization Act is amended to require the Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights to publicly disclose institutions under investigation, sanctions or findings, and program reviews under title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 or title IV of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Additionally, after termination of resolution agreements, a report must be transmitted to the Secretary, President, and Congress, and made publicly available. The Assistant Secretary for Postsecondary Education will publicly disclose institutions under investigation, sanctions, findings, and program reviews. The Inspector General of the Department of Education will review compliance and submit a report to Congress by January 1, 2016. The Inspector General of the Department of Education will review compliance with specific sections of the Department of Education Organization Act and submit a report to Congress. The Department of Education Organization Act is amended to allow fines to be imposed on institutions of higher education for violating laws under the Office for Civil Rights. The amount of the civil penalty will be based on the severity of the violation and will not prevent other legal remedies. Additionally, there will be provisions for climate surveys. Beginning October 1, 2017, institutions of higher education must conduct a sexual violence climate survey every 2 years, approved by the Secretary in consultation with relevant authorities. The National Intimate Partner and Sexual Violence Survey can be used until the new survey is developed. The sexual violence climate survey must be conducted by institutions of higher education every 2 years, assessing occurrences of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, stalking, discrimination indicators, and trends in intimate relationships. It also evaluates the effectiveness of campus policies for improving relationships between students regardless of gender or sexual orientation. The curr_chunk discusses the effectiveness of current processes for complaints and investigations into various forms of harassment, assault, discrimination, and violence based on sex, race, national origin, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability. It also includes issues related to discrimination based on these factors. The curr_chunk addresses discrimination, harassment, assault, domestic violence, dating violence, and assault based on sex, race, national origin, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability. The creation of a private right of action is addressed in Section 5, which focuses on discrimination, harassment, assault, domestic violence, dating violence, and assault based on various factors such as sex, race, national origin, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability. Section 485(f)(14) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow aggrieved individuals to allege violations in court and seek appropriate relief, including compensatory damages and remedial action. The statute of limitations for such actions will be determined according to the law. The limitations period for alleging violations under Section 485(f)(14) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 will be determined in accordance with 42 U.S.C. 1983 in the forum State. SEC. 6 amends the Clery Act penalties by increasing the fine to $100,000. SEC. 7 requires notification of policies for preventing sexual violence. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require institutions to provide a clear and easily accessible policy on preventing sexual violence. The policy must be written in simple language, posted on the institution's website, and distributed annually to student groups. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require institutions to have a policy on preventing sexual violence that must be distributed to student groups. Institutions must ensure that unaffiliated student groups also distribute this policy to their members and applicants. Compliance with this policy does not imply institutional recognition or endorsement of the student groups. The Comptroller General is required to report on this by August 1, 2017. The Comptroller General will report on the implementation of the Higher Education Act of 1965 regarding institutions' policies on preventing sexual violence, distribution of these policies, and oversight by the Secretary of Education. The Comptroller General will report on the compliance of institutions of higher education with policy requirements, including providing technical assistance. It will also cover changes in reported incidents of dating violence, domestic violence, sexual assault, or stalking. SEC. 8. CAMPUS SEXUAL VIOLENCE TASK FORCE. The Campus Sexual Violence Task Force will be established by the Secretary of Education and the Attorney General to provide information on prevention, investigations, and responses to campus sexual violence. It will also offer recommendations to higher education institutions on creating sexual assault prevention and response teams. The Campus Sexual Violence Task Force will develop recommendations for institutions of higher education on survivor resources, prevention practices, and assessing the Department of Education's ability to enforce compliance with title IX. The Campus Sexual Violence Task Force may levy fines for noncompliance with title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 and create a plan. Federal agency personnel funded under the Violence Against Women Act of 1994 can be detailed to assist the Task Force with its duties. The Campus Sexual Violence Task Force will submit a plan to Congress within 270 days of the Act's enactment for recruiting, retaining, and training a qualified workforce to investigate complaints of title IX violations and enforce related laws regarding campus sexual violence. The Campus Sexual Violence Task Force will submit a plan to Congress within 270 days of the Act's enactment for assessing workforce capabilities, recruiting, retaining, and training personnel to properly investigate and enforce laws related to campus sexual violence. This plan includes examining issues of workforce development, outreach and training with law enforcement agencies and higher education institutions, and developing best practices for interviewing. The Campus Sexual Violence Task Force will provide guidance on evidentiary standards, prevention practices, and strategies for addressing necessary matters related to campus sexual violence. They will also report annually to Congress on their activities and complaints received. The Campus Sexual Violence Task Force will report annually to Congress on activities related to sexual violence, including the number of complaints received, open investigations, average investigation time, and funding authorization for enforcement of Title IX provisions. The Higher Education Act of 1965 authorizes funding for training and retaining a workforce dedicated to investigating and enforcing section 485(f). The term "educational institution" includes higher education, elementary, and secondary schools. The term "school" and "institution of higher education" are defined in specific sections of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 and the Higher Education Act of 1965, respectively. The term "sexual assault" is defined as an offense that includes rape, fondling, incest, or statutory rape according to the Uniform Crime Report of the FBI and Department of Education regulations. SEC. 9. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to update the definition of "sexual assault" to align with the Uniform Crime Report of the FBI and Department of Education regulations.
